titleStmt.title: No interest beyond the principall or, The court camisado. By reduction of government to its primitive end and integrity, Rom. 13.4. The ruler is the minister of God to thee for good. Also, nevves from Scotland : or, the reasons examined of the warre threatned. May. 1. 1648. Imprimatur, Gilb. Mabbott.

titleStmt.title: No interest beyond the principall or, The court camisado. By reduction of government to its primitive end and integrity, Rom. 13.4. The ruler is the minister of God to thee for good. Also, nevves from Scotland : or, the reasons examined of the warre threatned. May. 1. 1648. Imprimatur, Gilb. Mabbott.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: NO INTEREST Beyond the PRINCIPALL OR, The Court CAMISADO. By Reduction of Government to its primitive end and Integrity,

q.p: The Ruler is the Mini≈øter of God to thee for good.

div.p: ALSO, NEVVES from SCOTLAND: OR, The REASONS Examined of the Warre THREATNED.
LONDON, Printed for H. Becke, and are to be ≈øold in the Old Bayley. 1648.

div.head: No Intere≈øt beyond the Principall. OR, The Court Cami≈øado.
div.p:
IN the ca≈øe of divorce, when it was put to Chri≈øt by the Phari≈øees to know his opinions in it, he being neither Scribe nor Phari≈øee, Mat. 19. of no ≈øect nor faction, one that drive no de≈øigne but Gods; and that came to fulfill the law, not to de≈øtroy it, ≈øends tho≈øe great doctors to Schoole, to the primitive end and in≈øtitution of marriage, as it came immediatly from God, in innocency, when, and where all things were very good, as he that will ta≈øte water purely mu≈øt doe it at the fountain. But they not ≈øatisfied with this ≈øolution by way of ju≈øtification, urge an old ≈øtatute Law of Mo≈øes, which by its antiquity, authority, and u≈øage might (as they thought) v. 7) plead right of pre≈øcription for that ma≈øculine priviledge of putting away their wives. But Chri≈øt tels them, that Plant never grew in innocency, God grafted no ≈øuch Sience in the ≈øtocke of created nature, it was a mu≈øhroome that grew out of nature corrupted. Mo≈øes (≈øaies he) bacau≈øe of the hardne≈øs of your hearts, ≈øuffered you to put away your wives, but from the beginning it was not ≈øo, as who ≈øay. It was indeed a politique law of conce≈ø≈øion, but policy mu≈øt not annull divinity, neither rea≈øon of ≈øtate, not laws municipal mu≈øt cro≈ø≈øewh ‚Ä¢ t with right rea≈øon, or the principles of entire nature. Therefore I, who am come to enlighten your judgements, and reforme your manners (Go≈øpell-properties) tell you againe that whatever your lu≈øts and exorbitancies might occa≈øion Mo≈øes to do, or enact, by way of connivance or permi≈ø≈øion, that does not ju≈øtifie the practi≈øe (though never ≈øo old, and generally received) to be lawful, but rather ≈øhew it to be unlawful,
becau≈øe that permi≈ø≈øion varies from the fir≈øt po≈øition or ≈øtandard given by God him≈øelf, the prime legi≈ølator, whither this ca≈øe if rightly ≈øtated and argued mu≈øt be reduced for ≈øolution, no authority binding above his, nor no law again≈øt his, though ≈øeemingly never ≈øo ≈øpecious.

A cleare demon≈øtration, which is the be≈øt way to an≈øwer que≈øtions and work reformations in matters of Government. Not to be mi≈ø-led by words of Art, civill ≈øuper≈øtition, or formall pretences, to the violation of the lawes of God, nature, or rea≈øon. It is true that Government (as marriage) is of God, but it is as true that governors (as per≈øons marrying) are of men, and that the great Intere≈øt (which word is now the onely Idol that men ≈øal down and wor≈øhip) of both Government and Governours is the glory of God, and the good of mankind: The end of the in≈øtitution is the onely intere≈øt of the thing in≈øtituted, and con≈øequently the Mea ‚Ä¢ e-wand or Standard by which it is to be regulated and reduced, though as old as Mo≈øes, when God gives opportunity, and time brings truth to light. In this age of ours, Kings plead for prerogative, flowres of the Crown, and right of Soveraignty, as they and their flatterers cal it. And even Parliament-priviledge is made u≈øe of by prerogative members, for promoting the arbitrary intere≈øt of the Crown; thus is authority wire-drawn, as if Governours rather then the Governed, were the end of Government, and Government it ≈øelfe is rather made a per≈øonall Intere≈øt, then a publique utility. Yea, Laws, nay Oathes, are thus made u≈øe of to captive & in≈ønare men, by prerogative glo≈ø≈øes, as if it wer in the power of men, who are the ≈øons of rea≈øon to ≈øwear them≈øelves into bea≈øts, and to abjure their very nature, and that by vertue of an ordinance of God, which Government is. What confidence can Kings have in people by ≈øuch ties as being ex natura rei unlawfull, do untie them≈øelves, and which are both unlawful to be taken, and when taken unlawfull to be kept. Such glo≈ø≈øes as Court Para≈øites, put upon lawes allegiance tending to make Kings ab≈øolute, and their power as well negative,
as po≈øitive, and their duty meere matters of plea≈øure, and acts of will, in the way neither to render Kings ≈øafe, nor their people happy.

The Popery of an implicit faith and blinde obedience, will not, cannot la≈øt alwayes; which becau≈øe it is ≈øo much countenanced by Epi≈øcopacy (that rag of Rome) therefore thence is that maxim. No Bi≈øhops, no King, implying that when ever the vail of ignorance and blind obedience was done away by aboli≈øhing of Bi≈øhops, and the peoples eyes were opened by divinity, and rea≈øon to ≈øee them≈øelves mi≈ø-led by pretence of authority from a right under≈øtanding of the nature of government, they will never endure to be ≈ølaves in≈øtead of freemen, ≈øubjects to governours in≈øtead of government, and to ≈øerve their intere≈øts who are their Mini≈øters and Gods meerly for their good, having their being (in office and authority) by, for, nor to no other end or purpo≈øe. For as the Pope is afraid of nothing ≈øo much as the tran≈ølating the word into popular languages for fear of betraying his jugling tricks in divinity, ≈øo nor Kings and Royalli≈øts then that the Lawes of the Land ≈øhould be Engli≈øh'd, I meane not ≈øo much in language, as in ≈øen≈øe and rea≈øon (though there is no good rea≈øon why Engli≈øh eyes ≈øhould look through French ≈øpectacles, except it be to ≈øee to lo≈øe our way to liberty and property as they have done) but for Engli≈øh Lawes to ≈øpeake Prerogative, is wor≈øe then to ≈øpeake French, ≈øome Commentators are better Courtiers then Lawyers, who ≈øhould be men of rea≈øon, and not ≈øo di≈øcredit the Law (the honour of their profe≈ø≈øion) as to force it again≈øt rea≈øon to advance the will of a man above the rea≈øon of a State, and the originall end of government it ≈øelfe. Therefore its time to be no longer fool'd with State tearmes of Intere≈øt, Jewels, and Flowers of the Crowne, or the old overworne word of Prerogative, for what is this but fir≈øt to ≈øet up a golden image, and then to fall downe and wor≈øhip it. I am not again≈øt Kings nor their Crownes, its the abu≈øe, and onely
that that I abominate, which hath as much blindfolded the people of Chri≈øtendome, as the Popes ≈øupremacy hath the Princes thereof, who≈øe eyes yet ≈øhall be opened to ≈øee their errour, and to withdraw their necks out of his Eccle≈øia≈øticall yoake, and ≈øo its hoped ≈øhall the peoples (≈øpecially Engli≈øhmen) in things Civil; to know, as their obedience to authority, ≈øo good authority in rea≈øon, ju≈øtice, and equity, for that their obedience; for ≈øo men act like men, el≈øe like bea≈øts, which only are ≈øubjected to will, which yet is not the lea≈øt part of that bondage of corruption the creation groans and travels in pain under, Rom. 8. 20, 21, 22. being unwillingly made ≈øubject to that vanity, in hope and earne≈øt expectation to be delivered: and ≈øhal we be ≈øo vaine, ≈øpecially when a price is new put into our hands, as willingly to take up that yoake which the creature, though ≈øen≈øele≈ø≈øe and irrationall, unwillingly beares, in hope of being infranchi≈øed of it at the la≈øt, accounting even annihilation better then ≈øubordination to the inordinate will of falne mankinde. Old errours are ≈øo much cryed up under new lights, as that old truths will ≈øcarce be believed again≈øt cu≈øtome in errour: Kings they will not, but tell you its again≈øt their intere≈øt not to be arbitrary, and the people they dare not believe it if the Princes doe not, though neither to 'ne nor to 'ther, but mu≈øt needs grant that ab initio non fuit ≈øic, its con≈øonant neither to the nature, nor the end of government; and con≈øequently not of Sovereignty, which onely ≈øo farre is ≈øovereigne as it is pre≈øervative. Therefore the Law ≈øayes (of al men) the King can doe no wrong, hath le≈ø≈øe power to doe wrong, becau≈øe greater obligation to doe right then any man el≈øe; nay he is ≈øo far from having power to doe wrong, that he is neither to doe it, nor ≈øuffer it to be done by any inferiour powers, but to ≈øee that ju≈øtice and protection according to Law be admini≈øtred to all by the Mini≈øters thereof, whereof hee's the chiefe.

But the nature, of man even in innocency (though not by it)
lu≈øteth after an exorbitant ≈øuperiority, for when God had made him Lord over all but the forbidden fruit, hee thought him≈øelfe no King over the creature whil≈øt the Creator limited his power, though but in one, and therefore he re≈øolves either to win the hor≈øe, or lo≈øe the ≈øaddle, gaine that, or lo≈øe all. So Kings, bee their power never ≈øo great to doe, yet except they may al≈øo have power to undoe, negative as well as po≈øitive, power to deny, as well as to grant, and undoe as well as doe, they are un≈øatisfied, and ≈øticke not in effect to affirme, that except you grant them Tyranny, you oppo≈øe Monarchy. Wherein yet they doe them≈øelves no right, nor tho≈øe that flatter them into ≈øuch principles: for when people ≈øee they cannot grant ≈øafe and lawfull premi≈øes, but with hazzard of ≈øophi≈øtical and prevaricate conclu≈øions to bee inferred thereupon, it makes them fearefull to grant any thing, le≈øt they lo≈øe all, an Inch given, makes an Ell taken. As if commi≈ø≈øions, &c. for honour-≈øake goe in the Kings name, then the Court con≈øequence is, they are the act, not his Laws; then the next re≈øult is, they are ad placitum, and not quamdiu bene ≈øe ge≈ø≈øerint, Prerogative is ≈øo procreant that no wombe is barren to the third or fourth generation, but every inference is productive of another. So let him have the honour to confirme and a≈ø≈øert Laws; then the next remove is, you mu≈øt allow him the u≈øe of his rea≈øon, and the next to that, therefore a negative as well as an affirmative voice: grant-freewill, and falling from Grace will follow. Suppo≈øe him the fountaine of honour; then, he retorts, I may conferre it on whom I plea≈øe, and for what cau≈øe, for vice as well as vertue. I may make George Villiers and his vertuous mother, Duke and Counte≈ø≈øe of Buckingham, and court-minions Privy-councellours, nay aliens of the Scotch Nation, (who≈øe native ≈øtate intere≈øt by vicinity, is again≈øt ours) Peers and Parliamentmen in England. Therefore lay the foundation upon the rocke, not in the ≈øands: make out that po≈øition in plain Engli≈øh, That the King can do no wrong, nor the Crown
neither, by declaring that neither legally nor illegally by abu≈øed law, or power above law, it neither is, nor ought to be in their power to do ≈øo, and provide accordingly, let legall and regall be but one and the ≈øame, as in ≈øound, ≈øo in a ≈øafe and ≈øound ≈øence, univocall tearmes: and ≈øoveraignty made ≈øoveraigne by preferring the Coronation Oath, with a right under≈øtanding; Magna Charta purged of ≈øuper≈øtition; and the Petition of Right well back'd with Propo≈øitions, to be principall flowers of the Crowne before it be worne againe in England, and that by a penall law: for if it be lawfull for a private man or particular ≈øubject to implead his Prince by law upon a particular wrong, much more for the State, or people in generall to implead him by armes, or proceed again≈øt him in ca≈øe of a generall wrong, when theirs, neither Law nor Judge, but ≈øalus popoli to determine betwixt them. And therefore Trajan both wi≈øely and worthily, when hee delivered the ≈øword to the Pretor, bid him u≈øe it for him whil≈øt he ruled well, and again≈øt him, when ill.

Let Kings have as much honour, freedome, and ≈øafety in the way of righteou≈ønes as becomes men of their place, the contrary whereof is di≈øhonour, ≈ølavery and danger both to Prince and people: Let the people know that his name is of no more u≈øe in commi≈ø≈øions and ≈øtatutes, then his Image and ≈øuper≈øcription upon coyn, the one arguing no more propriety or title in him then the other, the honour of both his is & that for publik advantage, not di≈øadvantage, he can no more ≈øu≈øpend the one, then the other, or de≈øtitute his people either of laws or their lawful execution, then of money and trade. Go≈øpel time≈øhould make our Kings better Chri≈øtians, then to de≈øire ≈øuch Catholike authority, when they ≈øee, heare, and read the evill effects that doe, and cannot but attend it, both to him that is in authority by way of temptation, and tho≈øe that are under authority by way of ruine and de≈øtruction. Giants of old, tho≈øe men-mon≈øters begotten of Gods di≈øplea≈øure, & inordinate concupi≈øcence, what effects had their exorbitancy of ≈øtrength but to make them men of exorbitant minds? proud & cruel, rebellious toward God, and tyrannous over men. A rea≈øonable ≈øize be≈øt befits a rea≈øonable man, too much power of any kind makes a man a mon≈øter, and hazzards him to do mon≈øtrous things. Nimrod was the fir≈øt we read of, that by inva≈øion and oppre≈ø≈øion of publique right and liberty affected a Babell Kingdome Government beyond rule, and to be ab≈øolute on earth as God is in heaven, therefore was he call'd The mighty hunter before the Lord, Gen. 10. 8, 9, 10. And every one after him that hunted inordinatly after power, as he
did, was proverbially called as he was, another Nimrod, or (as wee now ≈øay) Nimrod the ≈øecond, Nimrod the third, the mighty hunter &c. deriving both his name and ≈øtile, as the brand of his pre≈øumption, and unlawfull ambition or u≈øurpation. The account that Kings are to make for the talents that are lawfully conferred upon them is great enough, and need not be increa≈øed by the talents them≈øelves unlawfully u≈øurped. Abu≈øed power makes men on earth, the mo≈øt unlike to God in heaven of any thing, therfore unlimitted authority is uncompatible to a creature, and able to make a man a devill. Angels in heaven as well as Adam in paradi≈øe, fell by free-will and freewill power, and how then think we can Common-wealths ≈øtand by it, ≈øpecially in one man? That King that makes con≈øcience of his place and people, will rather think his power too much then too little, con≈øidering he mu≈øt an≈øwer for no more then he hath, and with Mo≈øes be content to depart of his ≈øpirit to le≈ø≈øen his charge for his own ea≈øe, and their benefit; and if he doe not, then a little is too much, for power without con≈øcience is like a hor≈øe without a bridle, ready to hurry the rider into ruine, and over-run al that ≈øtands in his way. Nor will a con≈øcientious King purcha≈øe power over his people again≈øt their wills, with the lo≈ø≈øe of their blood, his greater care will be to u≈øe that well he hath, and not to make his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors ab≈øolute, that his Subjects may be ≈ølaves, nor conquer whom he ≈øhould protect, he will as well remember that he is the father of his Country, as of his next Heire, who yet is but his ≈øucce≈ø≈øor, and the Kingdoms Heire, the Crown and Kingdome being an incorporate body, for he cannot di≈ø-inherit him, though the people may, and upon mi≈ø-government depo≈øe him, as in ca≈øe of adultery marryed people may divorce, the knot that ties them together, being broken a≈øunder: his care ≈øhould be rather to leave rules to his Son to govern well, then power to govern ill: and him≈øelf to dye de≈øired, as good Jo≈øiah did, rather then when he is dead, to be ≈øtiled of happy memory, becau≈øe of his unhappy Reigne. Would Kings be more Religious, they would be le≈ø≈øe ambitious, and ≈øee rea≈øon for it; yea, beleeve them≈øelves as well in debt to their people, as their people to them, owing both mutuall love and duty, ≈øtriving rather to de≈øerve obedience then to inforce it, and entituling them≈øelves to their peoples Allegiance rather by their admini≈øtrations then commands, them≈øelves inviolably keeping the Oath of good Government, that ≈øo they may not give their people the lea≈øt coulour of liberty, to breake the ‚Ä¢ e of dutifull Allegiance, and knowing how dangerous a thing „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ a Printe is both in
the ≈øad con≈øequence of ill example, and the wo≈øull effects of divine ju≈øtice, ≈øo frequently inflicted on the people either for or by occa≈øion of the Princes ≈øins.

What rea≈øon can be given why all other Governors and Magi≈øtrats are to rule for the publique good, and onely Kings for their owne greatning? No inferior authority hath a negative power to ≈øu≈øpend ju≈øtice or protection ≈øo farre as he is to admini≈øter it by his place, the King him≈øelf can derive no ≈øuch power to any, and if he cannot derive it, then he hath it not inherent in him≈øelf, for the Soveraignes power is principally to impower others. Magis and Minus make no e≈ø≈øentiall difference; Betwixt the King and a Con≈øtable there is difference of power in point of proportion, but not in ≈øpecie or kind, it is of the ≈øame kinde, and to the ≈øelf-≈øame end, one hath not power for, and the other again≈øt. Or what rea≈øon can be ≈øhowne, why the King ought to have a negative arbitrary power? is it becau≈øe Kings are more infallible, & unerring then other men? we have not found it ≈øo. Or what good rea≈øon can be ≈øhown that de facto he hath it? Hath any known law of the Land conferred it on him, or is it meerly by u≈øurpation? hath he taken it becau≈øe the people dur≈øt not deny it, as former Kings have done Forre≈øt-Lands, & then made the people undoe them by forre≈øt-Laws: why then, pre≈øcription in wrong, entitles no man to right, e≈øpecially Kings, who≈øe office is neither to do, nor ≈øuffer to be done, any wrong to the body whereof they are the head. Or is it as ≈øome affirme, becau≈øe the King is ≈øupreame? for ≈øay they, ≈øeeing arbitrary power mu≈øt be ≈øomewhere, therfore it is fitte≈øt to be in the ≈øupreme Magi≈øtrate. To this I An≈øwer, That arbitrary Legi≈ølative power is in the ≈øupreme Magi≈øtracy or Government, not Governour; the Parliament, not the King; for the people being a numerous di≈øper≈øed multitude, and ≈øo not fit alwayes to be together, to ≈øee to the execution of their own Laws, do therefore meet occa≈øionally in an aggregate body, for the con≈øultive, and creative part of Laws, and con≈øtitutions, that ≈øo they may be ≈øuch as are mo≈øt fit, and doe be≈øt ≈øute with the nature of the place and people; and then leave them for the executive part principally to the care of the King, with other ordained Mini≈øters, as being better executed by a few then a many, and better con≈øulted and made by a many then a few; & therfore hath he the honor of Sword & Scepter, and for that cau≈øe were good Kings in former times wont to goe their progre≈ø≈øes, as Judges doe their circuits, not to make hunting-matches, & hor≈øe-races, nor yet to give Laws, but to inquire and countenance the execution of
ju≈øtice, & pre≈øervation of peace, according to law, & puni≈øh the violators

And as Kings, ≈øo all other Governments and governors, their Intere≈øt is neither contrary to, nor diver≈øe from the publick good, their chief end is their cheif intere≈øt, neither power, priviledge, nor liberty to con≈øult, debate, or conclude, belongs to any (and to them lea≈øt that are intru≈øted mo≈øt) but what hath proximity with, is reductive to, and acted for, it; therfore tho≈øe Parliament-men who≈øe principles and tran≈øactions vary from that pole, they are the mo≈øt de≈øtructive members to Parliament-intere≈øt, that drive a Court de≈øigne with publick imployment, for Prerogative and Priviledge run the ≈øame danger, the apparent abu≈øe of ≈øame brings all into que≈øtion; potius unus quam unitas, better then throw out ≈øome rotten Apples, then ≈øpoyle the whole hoard; be not tenderer of your members then they are true to their tru≈øt, if the Common wealth ≈øee ≈øome made examples, the puni≈øhment of a few, will pre≈øerve the reputation of the whole, that the body is ≈øound, though ≈øome members be rotten: God made not man for him≈øelf, the intere≈øt of the creature, is the ≈øervice of his Creator, and therefore our ri≈øe was our fall, the rai≈øing of our intere≈øt, was the ruine of us all. He that being cho≈øen and intru≈øted with arbitrary power, wil therfore u≈øe it arbitrarily, is Adams own child, and after his likene≈ø≈øe. If it be objected, that the King pretends the publick intere≈øt in tho≈øe things which by ab≈øolute power he claimes and entitles him≈øelf unto, as the Militia, and negative voyce; that they are for the better protecting and rule of his people, and the Royall party in Parliament, for≈øooth, urge Liberty of con≈øcience, for liberty of ≈øpeech, Cum Privilegio, to betray their tru≈øt. To the≈øe I An≈øwer, fir≈øt Joyntly: That it is an ea≈øie matter to put a bait upon a hook, and no hard thing to catch Gudgins with it, but for my part I will never tru≈øt him, nor them, by the By, that erre in the main. Secondly, Severally, And fir≈øt for the Kings claim and pretences (which the effects have proved barely to be ≈øuch) in rea≈øon he can neither de≈øire it, if he know him≈øelf to be but man, nor his people grant it, to his, & their apparent ruine. Only blind Cupid is fit to ≈øtand a top of the wheel of Fortune, none that have eyes in their heads would de≈øire ≈øo ≈ølippery a place, when they ≈øee they ≈øo much over top them≈øelves that their hands cannot mannage what is under their feet, but they mu≈øt needs turn round to their own ruine. But if ≈øeeing they ≈øee not, and will venture their necks to have their wills, yet there is no rea≈øon the people ≈øhould build Babel to bring confu≈øion upon them≈øelves. VVi≈ødom is, to pur≈øue a right end by right means, con≈øequently, not to expect good government from a corrupt will, endowed with Arbitrary power. What hath bin the ruin of Empire, ≈øo much as Empire? Kings have lived to repent their power, and people much more.

And Secondly, for his party in the Parliament Priviledge in their hands is as bad as prerogative in his, they having no more right of power to abu≈øe that, then he this. Whoever repre≈øents a County or Corporation is entru≈øted by a part of member of the Common-wealth for the good of the whole, and is in the „Äà‚óä„Äâ of an Emba≈ø≈øador or Commi≈ø≈øioner to negotiate in a joynt body with the States Generall, for the State in generall. For by the Laws of Emba≈ø≈øie, State agents (though Plenipotentiaties) are not to betray them they treat for, their power is neither intended, nor ought to be interpreted to the prejudice but profit of them that imploy them. The Feffee for the Feffor. Liberty and priviledge are allowed to Parliaments, to tran≈øact the liberty, property, and ≈øafety of the people, and he that goes retrograde to tho≈øe, what place or part of the Common-wealth ≈øoever he ≈øerve for, by right of community ought to be rejected by the re≈øt that ≈øerve for, and are intru≈øted with the whole.

In a word, words by tract of time degenerate like men. Tirannus once was taken in the better part, when Kings were better common-wealthsmen, and that they and their people were joynt purcha≈øers, trading abroad & not at home, for preeminence. So was the word Intere≈øt, whil≈øt it was of publick cognizance, and all Qu. Elizabeths dayes kept it ≈øelf ≈øober by drinking Engli≈øh Be ‚Ä¢ re till it was made drunk with F ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ tiniack, and the King and his Courtiers by u≈øe upon u≈øe and intere≈øt upon intere≈øt had almo≈øt ≈øwallowed up all, the peoples Principall. And Rea≈øon it ≈øelf run hazzard to have her eyes put out, that Prapria que maribus, which was wont to be the common name for all men, it begun to be wholly ingro≈ø≈øed at Court, entailed upon the crown & begg'd for a Monopoly, in≈øomuch as there was almo≈øt no Rea≈øon left but Rea≈øon of State, within the compa≈ø≈øe of a cabinet councell, all el≈øe was either bruiti≈øh or rebell on, nor no ≈øtate but that of the King & his Royal con≈øort, the one Scatch, the other French. When publick Intere≈øt is impropriated ex officia, to private & per≈øonall purpo≈øes, then cea≈øeth the name & nature of a Governour by deviating from the primitive end & in≈øtitution of government, ordain'd by God & Nature; & con≈øequently love, loyalty, obedience, duty: for what oblieges the≈øe? not greatnes without goodnes, for then the devil might challenge them at our hands, who by Scripture is ≈øtiled principalities and powers, yea, the Prince of this world. Authority (whatever the kind or ≈øpecies of it be) while≈øt it points right to the pole, and retains the vertue of the Lord-≈øtone, where with it was fir≈øt touched, its ≈øafe to ≈øale by it, but if either through corruption, or injury of time, it make ≈øtanding variations at wrong points, then it mu≈øt either be new touched, or quite changed el≈øe contrary to intention, when fir≈øt ≈øea-≈øaile, youle make a wrong voyage, and fall among≈øt enemies in≈øtead of friends; or a de≈øtructive, and be ca≈øt among≈øt rock; and ≈øands in≈øtead of knowne Seas.

div.head: NEWES from SCOTLAND OR Their rea≈øons examined of the WARRE threatned.
div.p: THe Scots would faine make war upon England, but they are to ≈øeeke for a why and a wherefore; and are ready to fall together by the eares among≈øt them≈øelves what ≈øhall be the cau≈øe of the quarrell (yet keep us in continuall alarme to the lo≈ø≈øe of Ireland) for the world mu≈øt have a blind. But bee the rea≈øon never ≈øo politicke, Religion mu≈øt be the overture; which the Scotch dangerous Committee not being wi≈øe enough to reconcile, Traquire who of late was fir≈øt in their exception, and now in acceptation) was called to councell to help at a dead lift, being for michiavillian policy another Strafford.

One part of them ≈øay the Sectaries (meaning the Army) have broken the Covenant, which they never tooke.) But if breach of Covenant be a cau≈øe of quarrell, the Scots neede not goe ≈øo farre to fight, they have Covenant breakers nearer hand at home; is it po≈ø≈øible that ≈øuch pretenders to piety ≈øhould ≈øee a moat in their brothers eye ≈øo far off, and overlooke the beame that is in their own, ≈øtreyne at a gnat, and ≈øwallow a camel, threaten warre to England, for they them≈øelves know not what; one while ≈øaying the Covenant is broken, and another while that it is endangered; and the whil≈øt cocker up their owne Commi≈ø≈øioners with an omne bene, in their palpable Covenant-breaches and Apo≈øtacies. But it ≈øeemes they mu≈øt fall out with us, to keep them friends among≈øt them≈øelves; though if they had eyes in their heads, they might ≈øee Gods hand in creating ≈øuch fewds at home, to prevent the mi≈øchiefe they would bring abroad.

But wherein have the Army broken the Covenant? why principally for not being Presbyterians, for that in pretence with ≈øome, and reality with others, is made the chiefe, if not the only hinge that the Covenant winds and turnes upon, though the word Presbitery is not ≈øo much as once named in the Covenant, a weak foundation then to build a warre upon; but to ≈øtrengthen it, they ≈øay the Army have refu≈øed orders for their disbanding, and forced orders for their ≈øtanding (though the Parliament of England never told them ≈øo) but they forget what their Army did when it was ≈øent to but to disband their ≈øupernumeraries, which they flatly refu≈øed, and forcibly kept them a foot ≈øpite of the Parliament, and to the de≈øpite of the poor Country, that groaned under ≈øo heavy a burden of ≈øo heavy a body; and by the ≈øame force kept Carlile and Newca≈øtle, whether the Parliament would or no (by what clau≈øe in the Covenant or Treaty, is not knowne to this day) and the King of England too, in England, till they thought good to part with him, and that notwith≈øtanding all authority, rea≈øon or right to the contrary But the true rea≈øon why the Army (who≈øe greate≈øt fault in their faithfulne≈ø≈øe) is ≈øuch an eye ≈øore, it is becau≈øe by their meanes principally
their ≈øtrong party in England is much weakned, tho≈øe fine de≈øignes of a joynt intere≈øt, legi≈ølative propriety, and the Kings comming to London in freedome, honour, and ≈øafety, and other ≈øuch like, have been ≈øhrewdly di≈øappointed, by demoli≈øhing their eleven pillars, and line of communication at once. If the Parliament of England and their Army, were as mi≈øchievou≈øly di≈øpo≈øed as they would render them, and did beleeve breach of Covenant, cau≈øe of quarrell, they would never ≈øit ≈øtill, and ≈øuffer ≈øuch retrogradation as is daily, and declaratively acted in Scotland, from the Kingdoms, to the Kings Cau≈øe and Party, covenanted and fought again≈øt; nor their Committee of danger to denounce warre as they do: having a vi≈øible power on foote, to ≈øpoile their councels before they can bring them to maturity, and to fetch back what they carried hence, and tho≈øe Engli≈øh Malignants and Incendiaries that went hence, which contrary to Covenant they refu≈øe to deliver.

Brotherly love and charity covers a multitude of faults, and does not cry every failer for a breach of Covenant on neither ≈øide (no more than every di≈øcontent is a breach of wed-locke) e≈øpecially touching things of non-concernment and a Covenant ≈øo large, comprehen≈øive, and ≈øubject in many things, to various acceptations by its manner of penning. David in the 44. P≈øalme ≈øhewes what God counts breach of Covenant, when hee ≈øaith, ver≈ø. 17, 18. We have not dealt fal≈øly in thy Covenant: our heart is not turned backe. Now whether in this ≈øen≈øe the Lord Louden or the Lord Fairfax, the Scotch Papers and Practi≈øes, or the Parliaments declarations and long ≈øufferings have broken Covenant, let God and the World judge. As the Covenant warrants not breaking ≈øo nor fighting for breaking (much le≈ø≈øe a ≈øuppo≈øed one, and that in our own forme and intere≈øt) God is witne≈ø≈øe as of the Covenant ≈øo of the breach, and it properly belongs to him, not man to puni≈øh, ≈øave in their ≈øeverall places, vocations and intere≈øts, tho≈øe are the words of the Covenant, whereby the Scoti≈øh judicature, may and ought to que≈øtion their owne Scotch Covenant-breakers, but by no means to ≈øtretch their line over Tweed, and to make them≈øelves work in anothers Harve≈øt, to puni≈øh us and not them≈øelves, for things concerning us, not them. But it ≈øeems when the Covenant was fir≈øt made in Scotl. it was then re≈øolved it ≈øhould be broke in England, and that what≈øoever was acted cro≈ø≈øe to their de≈øignes, e≈øpecially of joynt intere≈øt, ≈øhould be the breach of it, el≈øe they will never bring in ≈øuch farre fetch'd unconcerning things into the account, as they do. When they have done ju≈øtice in Scotland, upon their apo≈øtalized Covenanters, Malignants, and Incendiaries, we in England will thanke them for their prayors and friendly animadver≈øions in what they can ju≈øtly taske us or probably ≈øu≈øpect us, of what kind, but not till then, nor further then that. For by the Covenant the ≈øupream judicatories of both Kingdoms re≈øpectively have only power to puni≈øh. Another party are angry and threaten warre becau≈øe wee will not receive the
King upon their tearmes, and let them exerci≈øe a legi≈ølative power (≈øo furiou≈øly driven on) here in England, for which they al≈øo urge the Covenant (that Scotch Magna Charta) which becau≈øe they made it, therefore they conceive they cannot breake it, a≈ø≈øuming a legi≈ølative power not onely in, but over poore England by vertue of it, for that they that are the makers, mu≈øt it ≈øeems be interpreters, and thus the Covenant which was intended by us unto liberty, was meant and is made u≈øe of by them unto our bondage; and the King his very party and cau≈øe Covenanted for, that was Covenanted and fought again≈øt, Mon≈øtrum horrendum. An ounce of Scoti≈øh confidence is more worth than a pound of Engli≈øh hone≈øty. Thus Traquier him≈øelf is become a Covenanter: Such game≈øters will never lo≈øe, what game ≈øoever they play at, that can play fa≈øt and loo≈øe, and make any thing of every thing; and from the words, mutuall advice and con≈øent mentioned in the eigth Article of the Treaty intitle them≈øelves to a joynt intere≈øt. and us to breach of Covenant and Treaty; whereas tho≈øe words imply only thus much, that as the war was managed by a joynt ingagement again≈øt a common enemy to both Nations, ≈øo that it ≈øhould not be ended by a peace tran≈øacted or treated by one Nation alone, without the privity and con≈øent of the other, that ≈øo neither of their intere≈øts might be damnified. Not that both of them ≈øhould be confounded. The rare contradictions that their Papers, and Practi≈øes hold forth; ≈øometimes the King mu≈øt not come to London till he have given ≈øecurity and ≈øatisfaction, then again be mu≈øt come without either; ≈øometimes propo≈øitions and no per≈øonall treaty, othertimes a per≈øonall treaty and no propo≈øitions; which now are impo≈øitions; ≈øometimes the King mu≈øt take the Covenant, otherwhile if be come not to the length of our de≈øires, in ≈øo doing, we mu≈øt be content; ≈øometimes they tell the King upon his refu≈øing the Propo≈øitions both Kingdomes will be con≈øtrained (for their mutuall ≈øafety) to agree and ≈øettle Religion and Peace without him; and then upon turne of the tide they tell us we mu≈øt wait till God change his heart: For the ≈øafety of the Kingdome the Army mu≈øt be Disbanded, and the King inve≈øted in the Militia, or it in him. Sure Janus is Propitious to the≈øe ambidexers, el≈øe they could never ≈øo bewitch wi≈øe men as well as fools with their Sorceries as they doe, and with the Preshyterian Eele-hooke draw the City and A≈ø≈øembly after them, and that not onely in England, but in Scotland al≈øo, where (they ≈øay) they have deluded the well-meaning Clergy, who are con≈øented to joyn with tho≈øe Covenant-breakers in a warre again≈øt us, provided it be for Covenant-breaking. The little good that we have got, by the great cvills that we have undergon, God ju≈øtly may, and it may be will puni≈øh us for it, but they for their di≈ø≈øembling ≈øhal not ≈øcape, hypocri≈øie and fal≈øehood is as hateful to God as to man. I doubt not but the i≈ø≈øue will prove it ≈øo, according to their own prayer or forme of thanksgiving upon their deliverance from the French by the aid of the Engli≈øh, in the≈øe words‚ÄîSuffer us never O Lord to fall to
that Ingratitude, and dete≈øtable unthankefullnes, that we ≈øhall ≈øeek the de≈øtruction and death of tho≈øe, whom thou ha≈øt made In≈øtruments to deliver us from the tyranny of mercile≈ø≈øe ≈øtrangers. Di≈ø≈øipate thou the councells of ≈øuch, as deceitfully travell to ≈øtirre the hearts of the inhabitants of either Realm again≈øt the other let their malitious practi≈øes be their owne confu≈øion.‚ÄîBut that which I admire is, that they ≈øhould joyn and unite in Scotland, to get England, (though with hazzard of their owne) and that wee will not do the like to keepe it, are wee ≈øo ≈øtout ≈øtomacked, and our malice ≈øo implacable, that we will rather lo≈øe a good land than ≈øhake hands and be friends amongst our ≈øelves. I meane not the Malignant Cavaliers (tho≈øe excrements of Engli≈øh-men) of whom I dare prophecy they ≈øhall never hurt any but them≈øelves, nor doe much more harme (though they may often attempt it) then break gla≈ø≈øe windows, and write libellous pamphlets) but the mi≈ø-under≈øtanding City and Clergy, who doe well to oppo≈øe errour, ≈øo be that they them≈øelves erre not fundamentally in doing ≈øo, and cau≈øe the lo≈ø≈øe of all, or hazzard it, who have ≈ømal cau≈øe to think, they that are for the King will be for Presbytery. I am no Independent (≈øave as to the Scots) but an Engli≈øh-man, were all of us ≈øo, true to Engli≈øh principles, and intere≈øt, as the Scots are to theirs, they dur≈øt never ≈øet foot upon Engli≈øh ground in a war-like way. See we not how it hath been their con≈øtant practi≈øe and indeavor to ≈øet England on fire, that they might come in by the light of it, and ≈øhall we by our differences pave them a way, and open them a two leaved doore to enter in at, and march into the bowels of our Kingdome by, have we fought for the freedome of our≈øelves and po≈øterity, and ≈øaved it as a brand out of the fire, to be cheated out of it at the la≈øt? What made this Kingdome bee ≈øo often conquered, from the Romans to the Normans, but dome≈øticke differences, and ≈øhall it now be our fate to become conquerable by tho≈øe we our ≈øelves have ≈øo often conquered, through di≈ø-union.

Beleeve not their overtures, be they never ≈øo ≈øpecious, Thei'le tell you thei'le not joyne with Malignants and Cavaliers (as the King and the Earle of Newca≈øtle gave out they would not joyn with Papi≈øts) whereas they do not only already receive theÃÑ & joyn with them, but them≈øelves are ≈øuch, faced quit about to the King and his cau≈øe, whereof they have given the≈øe good ≈øignes among≈øt others, they have received Commi≈ø≈øion from him to make Malignant Knights and Lords, that ≈øit in their Parliament, and to gratifie the King again have retorted Traquier and imployed him as a confiding man, in Emba≈ø≈øie to the King in the I≈øle of Wyght beleeving the King will give more credit to him that hath been true to his principles, then to them that are fal≈øe to theirs
